text.p: These are the stories making headlines in the Namibian newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The lack of government policy is the cause of the current spate of land disputes such as those of the Kxoe and Gham communities, says the Namibia Non-governmental Organisations' Forum (Nangof).
- Output at the Okorusu fluorspar mine north-west of Otjiwarongo is expected to double as a result of the recent takeover of the mine by Belgium-based chemical and pharmaceutical group Solvay.
- Last Thursday president Sam Nujoma announced the winners of this year's Africa leadership prize for fighting hunger and poverty, President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique and Joyce Banda of Malawi.

- Defence minister Philemon Malima has expressed concern about the possibility of the resumption of civil war in Angola with an increase in airtraffic in the border areas under UNITA control and a resumption of training of soldiers at Jamba.
- Following the devastating drought, the commercial farming sector will save about N$22 million in livestock tax, which has been waived for this year and is expected to be done away with completely.
